channelDetails.title: Space is an Ecology of Systems

contents.title: Gestural Interaction - Jamie Zigelbaum
contents.description_html: We are experimenting and getting revved up. What is so exciting is the ability to breakdown the essential dichotomy of interface and destroy the gatekeeper, freeing humans to do what they do best and stop the crippling effect of tools that disregard ganglia by the fistful (for example the little bundles of neurons that allow us to express ourselves bodily, receive nuanced impressions through touch, and navigate 3D space).

contents.title: Disturbing Neufert II
contents.description_html: What is a dinner table, a sofa, a stair, a door, a street, a road, what are the human dimensions, also what are the dimensions of chicken or a pig ... how do we eat, work, live, sleep, etc.... Neufert answers everything, we just have to search it on the index.

contents.title: Creating Livable City Streets
contents.description_html: In 1981, a Berkeley urban design professor named Donald Appleyard published a book called Livable Streets (now out of print). In it, he described the results of research he'd done in the late 1960s about the effects of car traffic on the people who live in cities.
contents.description: In 1981, a Berkeley urban design professor named Donald Appleyard published a book called Livable Streets (now out of print). In it, he described the results of research he'd done in the late 1960s about the effects of car traffic on the people who live in cities.

metadata.description:
I'm a cyborg slime-mold brain fungus piloting a complex exosuit made of flesh. An ant consuming interestingness and extruding insight porn. Trying to figure out my place in the world while maintaining homeostasis. Wandering scholar, and informavore. 

----

Are.na is where I persist my external memories.

contents.title: The Psychology of Architecture
contents.description_html: We spend our lives inside buildings, our thoughts shaped by their walls. Nevertheless, there's surprisingly little research on the psychological implications of architecture. How do different spaces influence cognition? Is there an ideal kind of architectural structure for different kinds of thinking?
contents.description: We spend our lives inside buildings, our thoughts shaped by their walls. Nevertheless, there's surprisingly little research on the psychological implications of architecture. How do different spaces influence cognition? Is there an ideal kind of architectural structure for different kinds of thinking?

contents.title: What is the Prepared Environment?
contents.description_html: Bright, inviting, warm, and beautiful. These are a few descriptive words that typify the Montessori environment, fascinating both children and adults alike. One must ask, "How does a classroom become so inviting, beautiful and conducive to learning?" The answer emerges from one facet of the environment itself - the Montessori teacher, or guide.
contents.description: Bright, inviting, warm, and beautiful. These are a few descriptive words that typify the Montessori environment, fascinating both children and adults alike. One must ask, "How does a classroom become so inviting, beautiful and conducive to learning?" The answer emerges from one facet of the environment itself - the Montessori teacher, or guide.

contents.title: Appropriate technology
contents.description_html: Appropriate technology is a movement (and its manifestations) encompassing technological choice and application that is small-scale, decentralized, labor-intensive, energy-efficient, environmentally sound, and locally autonomous. It was originally articulated as intermediate technology by the economist Dr. Ernst Friedrich "Fritz" Schumacher in his work Small is Beautiful.
contents.description: Appropriate technology is a movement (and its manifestations) encompassing technological choice and application that is small-scale, decentralized, labor-intensive, energy-efficient, environmentally sound, and locally autonomous. It was originally articulated as intermediate technology by the economist Dr. Ernst Friedrich "Fritz" Schumacher in his work Small is Beautiful.

A Mind Made Out of Silk
contents.generated_title: A Mind Made Out of Silk
contents.description_html: Millions of years ago, a few spiders abandoned the kind of round webs that the word "spiderweb" calls to mind and started to focus on a new strategy. Before, they would wait for prey to become ensnared in their webs and then walk out to retrieve it.

contents.title: Experiments In Spatial Dynamics: RAAAF
contents.content_html:
Throughout the history of philosophy, the human mind has traditionally been considered as the origin of all theoretical journeys or physical fluctuations. “We tend to think that behavior starts with an intention in our head. It’s a typical assumption made in philosophy, but also in neuroscience and other fields,” Erik explains. “But research in embodied cognitive science shows that the origin of action is typically something else, namely affordances.
Affordances are the possibilities to act upon something. A chair offers the possibility to sit; a cup to drink; a bike to ride. That means, the human environment that we find ourselves in has been structured based on all these options. Once you’ve acquired the skill to sit on a chair or ride your bike, you can respond to these affordances without reflecting. This is why we should start thinking of action as a means to joining forces with environmental affordances rather than as an individual’s intention, which partly turns the mind into something external.”
contents.description_html: http://www.freundevonfreunden.com/workplaces/raaaf/
contents.content:
Throughout the history of philosophy, the human mind has traditionally been considered as the origin of all theoretical journeys or physical fluctuations. “We tend to think that behavior starts with an intention in our head. It’s a typical assumption made in philosophy, but also in neuroscience and other fields,” Erik explains. “But research in embodied cognitive science shows that the origin of action is typically something else, namely affordances.
Affordances are the possibilities to act upon something. A chair offers the possibility to sit; a cup to drink; a bike to ride. That means, the human environment that we find ourselves in has been structured based on all these options. Once you’ve acquired the skill to sit on a chair or ride your bike, you can respond to these affordances without reflecting. This is why we should start thinking of action as a means to joining forces with environmental affordances rather than as an individual’s intention, which partly turns the mind into something external.”
contents.description: http://www.freundevonfreunden.com/workplaces/raaaf/
